Description: Mould-made pottery plastic lamp in the form of a lantern flanked by two erotes holding torches. Below each figure is a short semicircular nozzle, projecting from a deep plinth. On the front of the lantern in relief is a shrine of Aphrodite, or perhaps Athena, in the form of a gabled building supported by columns, containing a standing female figure in a long chiton, resting her left hand on a shield. The domed top of the lantern has a pierced lug. The back of the lamp has a large semicircular cut-out for fuel. The front is covered with a red slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant mica, organics and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr Ernest Arthur Gardner
Curator's comments: Published in C. D’A. Tremblai, Athena en Égypte: syncrétisme iconographique et religieux. PhD Université Laval, Québec, 1992 (UMI), 123 no. 74, pl. 18 fig. 61. Parallel from Alexandria (Adriani 1939, 54; Bailey 1975, 279). Adriani, A. 1940, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du musée Gréco-Romain, Volume II (1935-1939), Alexandria.
Appears on Gardner 1888, pl. XV, which is labelled 'Aphrodite and Town.'
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q609)
Walters 1914 / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Lamps in the British Museum (pl. 4, fig. 3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.069) (Phase 1)
